Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling the regulatory network of inositol phosphate signaling in plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The inositol phosphates are a class of compound that in plants is thought to play a role in sensing (and making available) energy for the plant to grow and develop. The goal of this project is to understand how inositol phosphates are used to sense the energy status of plant cells, and how they signal this status so that the plant can use this information. The knowledge gained from this project is relevant to plant-derived bioenergy (e.g. biofuels); it will lead not just to an improved understanding but also to strategies to manipulate and maximize bioenergy for desired outcomes such as increased agricultural production of food and biofuels. The project will provide unique, interdisciplinary training in plant science, biochemistry and bioengineering for students and postdoctoral fellows. Outreach activities will focus on engaging high school students in authentic scientific inquiry with a variety of plants generated from this project, using an established program called the Partnership in Research and Education using Plants. Project personnel will also engage elementary students through a 4 day experience called Kids Tech University.

This project will utilize biochemical, genetic and computational modeling approaches to define the inositol pyrophosphate kinase protein interaction network (which includes the sucrose non-fermenting related kinase 1 in plants and the VIP kinases that generate inositol pyrophosphates) in the plant Arabidopsis thaliana and provide knowledge of its role in sensing and signaling a high or low energy status in the plant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

As sessile organisms, plants need to be able to sense and respond to changes in their environment. Inositol pyrophosphates (PPx-InsPs) are novel class of signaling molecules implicated in plant nutrient and energy sensing.  In this collaborative project, we sought to identify the pathways that generate and break down PPx-InsPs as well as identify their functions in plant development. We are particularly interested in the role of PPx-InsPs in plant phosphate signaling and homeostasis.  Phosphate limitation severely impacts crop production worldwide. Furthermore, phosphate fertilizer stores are finite and excess fertilizer application can lead to pollution of fresh water reservoirs. Therefore, it is important to understand how plants sense phosphate limitation and design strategies for better uptake and utilization of bioavailable phosphate.     

In this project we identified and characterized enzymes in the pathway and created mutants of these enzymes to understand their physiological impact. This work has helped uncover the complex regulation of plant phosphate homeostasis and the interplay between different PPx-InsP species. We also created tools to visualize intracellular location and regulation of the key enzymes.  With our collaborators in Engineering we utilized modeling approaches to better understand the regulation of the pathway.

 

Broader Impacts:

This project supported and trained one MS student, one graduate student and several undergraduates including students from our summer REU program.  Mutants and resources developed in this project were used in a laboratory based teaching course. The PI and student regularly attended the GRC conference on plant lipids and presented their research.  Additional outreach efforts have been largely coordinated with our collaborators at Virginia Tech, where we participated in our annual outreach event at James Madison High school in Fairfax VA. Students are exposed to the scientific method; they design and test hypotheses and develop communication skills.
